rsbNotes.title: Pr 27:3–4
rsbNotes.text: 27:3, 4 Two comparisons emphasize the destructiveness of folly.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 27:5
rsbNotes.text:
27:5 open rebuke. A salutary word aimed at correction for one’s good.

hidden love. This love, though genuine, lacks the moral strength to risk giving a rebuke.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 27:6
rsbNotes.text: 27:6 wounds of a friend. The meaning is similar to “open rebuke” in v. 5.
